reviewText: I happened to catch a small review of this little treasure in my  local paper, and seeing it was the kick-off to my birthday weekend. Turns out to have been a perfect present, and speaking as a "Celtophile" from since forever, I scarcely can contain my  enthusiasm for this film.  When people come together and get everything so just right about a project we all feel and benefit from it.  Moore's team has a rich pool of myth to dive into with the vast array of tales from the Irish tradition. I am loving how they draw that into a contemporary tale and allow us to see the relevance of myth in our lives today. Not just the selkies, but Mannanan macLir, the goddess Macha, and Finn's hunting hounds Bran and Sceolan all make appearances and have their human counterparts in the story. I loved the message of what  is magical in life really being what infuses our own with meaning and joy. I have to say, I am ordering the DVD, as this deserves more than one viewing for sure.  Not to be missed!

Based on the legend of the Selkies, "Song of the Sea" is a visual feast of hand-drawn art in a feature-length animated film.  The story is sufficiently complex to engage adults, yet is focused on kids.  It's a true joy to watch, and very deserving of the Oscar for which it has been nominated. Buy it, view it, and save it to view again or share with your grand kids.

This is the first movie we took our 4.5 year old twins to see in a movie theater.  My husband and I are huge fans of Secret of Kells, but feel it is a little bit too violent for 4.5 year olds so we were very excited when Song of the Sea was released.  As we sat in the theater we were a little bit concerned that the material might be too dark for our children, but as soon as we left the theater they asked to see it again.

My husband and I found the film visually and thematically exquisite and one doesn't need an understanding or appreciation of Celtic mythology to love it.  The music is dreamy and the pace is a refreshing change from the overstimulating fare that abounds in our culture.  While we were watching the movie, all of us were swept away by it.  And, entertaining as it was, it also sparked meaningful discussions. A remarkable film.

Thank you Tomm Moore!

One of the most beautiful things you'll ever see. Not just animated films, or films, but just in general. This is a work of art, and you could literally pause this film, at any second, screen capture that moment, and have something you could proudly hang up on your wall, or at the very least have as wallpaper on your computer. The sad truth is, the kids weren't as glued to the story and fi;m as much as I am. Otherwise I'd give it a full 5 stars. It's brilliant.

We folk of the Emerald Isle don't get to watch a lot of children's entertainment from our own fair country. So when I learned that the folks behind the beguiling and utterly beautiful The Secret of Kells were making The Song of the Sea, a magical fairy tale steeped in Irish folklore and mythology...I knew I had to see it as soon as possible. I was not disappointed! The Song of the Sea is a magical, poetic, moving, and beautiful little tale that will entrance children without talking down to them. The visuals are stylized and rich, and just plain beautiful. More importantly, Song of the Sea has got a big heart and lots of charm.

The story goes like this: Ben and Saoirse (said seer-sha) live in a lighthouse with their father Conor. One night, Saoirse is taken into the ocean by seals, where it's revealed she's a selkie: a magical being that takes the form of a seal in the sea. When Ben and Saoirse are sent to live with their grandmother in the city, they must step up to face their inner fears and complete a task to keep the magic stories alive.

I recommend this magical film to kids and adults alike. Come and share in the wonders of Ireland.
As they say in Gaelic, go raibh mle maith agat!

Song of the Sea is probably the most magical animated movie I've ever seen.  Based on the Irish legend of the selkie (girl who turns into a seal), the artists have created not only a quest story but also glorious visual moments.  Older brother Ben becomes involved in a quest to save his little sister for whom he's felt nothing but jealousy or annoyance so far during their lives.  In their journey he becomes heroic by protecting, saving, risking his life and eventually loving her. Most inspiring are the animated water-color scenes, mystical figures from Irish mythology, toe-tapping music and a moving story.  Don't miss it.
Excellent, great morals, fantastic story. Stunningly beautiful and entertaining even for young kids.

This is one of the most stunningly beautiful movies I have ever seen!!!!

I loved it so very much! The story is both wonderful and sad. The characters are fantastic!

This is one movie I will watch over and over. I could also listen to that song every single day!

I recommend to everyone!

A tale for all ages about family, loss, unintended consequences, love and redemption. Several cultures have legends about the Selkie, but this is firmly about the Celtic folklore of selkies, fairies, trolls, witches and owls. It is a gorgeous movie of what appears to be hand-drawn animation rather than CGI.

The film focuses on a family that has been torn apart by the death/disappearance of the mother. Their grandmother takes them to the city, away from their lighthouse-keeper father.  Bringing the family together is the plot of the film and it is the two children who battle the forces of Macha to return to their father.  Macha, also known as the Owl Witch in this story, aims to remove feelings from all humans so they feel no pain or sorrow.  As she drains them of their feelings, they turn to stone.  Breaking that spell allows the characters to fully experience life, not just joy and laughter but also  sorrow and pain, for all are essential to appreciating our life and helping us choose our path in it.
we loved it!!

Like Tomm Moore's The Secret of Kells, this is another animated movie involving Irish history and folklore. This one is about selkies, which are humans that must transform into seals at a certain age. Like The Secret of Roan Inish, another movie about selkies, this one is also about a family thrown into disarray when a selkie mother is forced to leave her human family, but it tells a much different story. While Roan Inish is more of a mystery, Song of the Sea is an adventure, and a beautiful, whimsical and sometimes heart-wrenching one at that. It uses the same medieval illustration style found in The Secret of Kells, but it looks even better and is even more magical here, and even though it's a strictly Irish story, it takes cues from Miyazaki's fantasy adventures such as My Neighbor Totoro and Spirited Away. Not to take away from Moore's unique approaches to animation and storytelling, but if you're a Miyazaki fan who is in the mood for something similar, Song of the Sea will satisfy your craving.
SO CUTE!!!

This is one of my favorite movies - not just as a kids' movie, but as a movie in general. The watercolor artwork is uniquely stunning, full of hidden details like ancient Celtic spirals, symbols, and Ogham characters for those who look closely! Music is delightfully done, and the story has lessons in emotional literacy for younger children as well as paralleled themes and character motifs for older viewers. I've watched this movie with children ages 4-9, all of whom seemed to enjoy it - including myself!
This movie is beautifully done:  the art, the music and the voices are all delightful.  It deserved the Oscar nomination that it received.  Heart warming magical storytelling.
This is the sweetest,  cutest movie ever!  My daughter adores it.

I love this movie. I watched it with my family (we love all the films made by Cartoon Saloon, including the Secret of Kells and The Breadwinner) and I was not disappointed. The fluid 2D animation is stunning, the music enchanting and trance-like, and the acting on point. 2D animation is so rare these days, as is a good theatrically animated story (apart from whenever Disney wants to be original and not churn out a sequel) and the story in this film is so ENGAGING! I could not look away.  The only problem with the video was the quality of the picture (Amazon Video's fault) and the fact that it LOADS EVERY 2-5 MINUTES. I've seen people giving this movie one star. They say it was "too slow in the beginning" so they didn't bother to watch the whole thing (which if they had stayed long enough they would quickly change their mind) or they said it was "too scary for the kiddos" which, honestly, don't just assume that because something is animated it will be all mindless blabber like Illumination Films. They tell you under the rating why it is PG. It has some thematic and scary elements. Watch the movie by your self before showing it to your kids.  There is actually a conflict and something at stake in this movie, and if your kid cannot get past the beginning, maybe consider their age to be a factor. Overall, I loved this movie. I recommend it to anyone mature enough to understand it's complexity. Watch it.

I'm not sure what else to say beyond the title. I wasn't sure what to expect going into this movie, but what I got was beautifully animated, well written, well acted, and touching, with some lovely music on top of it all. Also, they seem to have drawn from authentic Irish folklore for many of the characters, and if so, that would make this movie an interesting window into a rather under-served area of mythology. Maybe this film will inspire people to learn more about the giant and the owl witch and the selkies and the fellow with all the hair. I also liked that the dog's name is Cu, which is Gaelic for "dog" or "hound".
Honestly, I can't think of anything I'd change about this. I wish there could be a short film about how the father and mother met, given what we learn about them, but you can't have everything; where would you put it all?

This movie is an eclectic masterpiece of audio/visual art, appropriate for all ages. I'm a 26y/o male, and it tears at my soul in a way that I can't describe. It shows the nature of children, and our angelic intentions to explore the world around us, without taking understanding for granted. It's very touching, and an emotional Rollercoaster. I've seen many Miyazaki films and many animated movies, but the song of the sea has a special magic that I will treasure for years to come, easily one of my favorite movies /artistic experiences to enjoy, telling the tale of an older brother struggling to be what he thinks is the model he should be, for his younger mute (won't speak) sister, as she is compelled to change her life, but cannot express how she feels, or why, the brother slowly realizes their intimate and delicate family connection shared, and becomes a better and more compassionate person. A mesmerizing adventure, and the music is very inspiring as well.

In short, this movie is "angelic and full of wonders"
Absolutely stunning movie. A true treat for any fan of great animation and or just great story telling! :)

This is one of the best movies I've seen in awhile, whether aimed at children or adults. If you love mythology and legends, then this movie will have a lot for you, but even if you don't, there's still a wonderful story and beautiful art. All of my children love it, over an age spread of seventeen down to four years old. It can be hard for us to find something to suit everyone, but this was one movie that did. I was concerned as a parent on viewing it initially, that the brother is incredibly mean to his little sister. If you are a parent, you probably have some of this going on in your house anyhow, and you surely don't want to promote it. However, I was glad to see that the older brother comes to understand the error of his ways. Personally, I don't mind the family viewing behavior in films that is incorrect, as long as the behavior is shown to be incorrect. All of the characters are flawed, and their flaws hurt other characters, but I suppose I'd rather have this portrayed (it is realistic, in life, this really happens) than to have a story where some or all the characters are either completely evil, or almost completely without flaws. Stories can help us see and cope with our own failings if they mirror real life in an honest way. This story does that, setting the very believable characters into a context of legendary and magical events. Something I especially liked was that many plants were represented in a way that is botanically correct! That level of attention to detail was echoed throughout the film. Like The Secret of Kells, it is truly visually and artistically masterful. I would say that everyone should view this movie, and share it with others to enjoy as well. It really has something for everyone.
My 6 year old daughter and I really loved this film. The big, goofy, dog and the way that magic was portrayed made for a surprisingly heart warming adventure.

A treasure and masterpiece like The Secret of Kells. Tom Moore is knocking it out of the park with these films. Song of the Sea is an enchanting, magical tale rooted in Irish folklore. One of my children died several years ago, and it is very clear to me and my husband when a movie is made by someone who understands that type of pain and a movie that doesn't. Incredibly beautiful movie with captivating animation, enchanting music, and an inspiration story line. We bought this movie and our children LOVE it. They ask to watch it all the time. I am so thankful this movie exists to bring peace and healing to those who need it, and to entertain and inspire everyone.

People keep harping on about how sad and horrible it is for children. This is an absolutely stunning from an animator, artist, and story writing perspective. The ending is happy and the adventure is exhilarating. It surpasses Secret of Kells in my opinion, but both were very clever. It has good messages, good music, and fantastic artistic expression.

It is definitely not a "Disney" appropriation of an Irish cultural story. Enjoy.

In today's over-exaggerated and fast-spoken world of Disney animations, this soulful piece is truly refreshing.  It leaves you, and the kids, feeling contemplative, relaxed and at peace, upon watching.  We need more films like this and by director Hayao Miyazaki.  In fact, I see many similarities between this and Miyazaki's films, such as the artful use of silence (in comparison, Disney films seem obnoxiously loud) and the connection to the spiritual world.

I highly recommend introducing these films to children to cultivate a deeper sense of curiosity of not only their surroundings, but life in general.  My children love this film, along with all of Hayao Miyazaki's collection.

If you are a member or a descendant of the northern seafaring folk of Ireland, Scotland, and the Scandinavian countries, you may know what a selkie is. Or if you're a fan  of folk music, you may know about the tragic ballad, The Great Selkie of Sule Skerry.
 If not , Ill explain that a selkie is what could be called a shape-shifter. On the land, he or she has human form; in the sea it becomes a seal. The selkies are beautiful and seductive creatures who mate with humans and produce offspring. But in some tales they must eventually return to the sea as seals.
 "The Song of the Sea" is about two selkies, a mother and her daughter who knows nothing about her heritage. The mother returns to the sea while the daughter is still an infant, and we flash forward five or six years to find the daughter and her older brother taken from their seaside home by their paternal grandmother to live in the city. The balance of the story finds them struggling to return to their home and their father, and to protect the world of mythology.
 Their adventures provide the conflict and suspense of a good story, and the underlying knowledge that the daughter is a selkie provides mystery.
 But to my mind, the greatest attraction of this little movie is the beautiful artwork throughout. We have a controlling visual theme that unites the scenes into a consistent and solid work of art. As an old geezer with inadequate hearing I often missed what the children were saying, but the action and the art more than made up for the lack of subtitles. Next time I watch it Ill wear my hearing aids. And I will watch it again. Several times.

Young Ben loses his mother on the night of his baby sister's birth. Years later, his grandmother takes the two children to live with her, believing that her son has sunk too far in his grief and depression to properly care for him.

But when Ben's little sister Saoirse (Seersha) plays the shell flute their mother left them and releases a long held magic, the two youngsters begin a journey that will lead them home in more than one way. Ben will have to call on his memory of the fairy tales and songs his mother taught him to save his sister and set right the wrongs among the fairies. Along the way he'll have to repair his relationship with Saoirse and learn the truth about his much mourned mother.

Whether your family has ancestry drawing from the Isles or not, this is a great movie the whole family will love.

A funny, sweet, and heartbreaking movie about family that draws on Irish folklore but is at the same time utterly modern in its sensibilities. The visual style is very simple, almost stylized, against the backdrop of a very rich story in which mythical and real-world characters are trapped in the unintended consequences of decisions made with the best of intentions. This is not a movie for very small children; the child protagonists do face dangers and separation from their father, the story begins with the implied death of the mother in childbirth, and the nuances of the family dynamics may be lost on very young viewers. Despite this, my 8- and 11-year-olds have returned to the movie for its non-patronizing portrayal of children, myth-laden story, and quirky dialogue and characterization again and again (and we still laugh and cry every time).
Very touching movie.  Almost Miyazaki-like in ways, which means there's plenty for adults to appreciate and ponder as well.  Artwork/animation is different, but never detracts from the story.

This movie was surprisingly touching. It had me and my sons laughing and crying throughout this well-crafted masterpiece. It touches delicately on such topics of death in the family, growing up, family responsibilities, and the importance of emotions. Almost as magical as The Secret of Kells.  But in this offering some of the charm is missing.  The story features a bully older brother named Ben who treats his mute sister Saoirse abominably.  Dear old dad is distant and distraught ever since his wife, their mother, disappeared into the sea.  He decides to send them to the city to live with their formidable Granny who is a tyrant.  But the faerie folk have a kinship with Saoirse and the witch Macha wants her for reasons unreasonable.  This requires an abrupt change in Ben as he fights to protect and save his little sister from forces he doesnt fully understand.

The hand drawn backgrounds are exquisite, the character artwork less so.  The story is a bit of a downer as it deals with grief and the seduction of losing ones sorrow, becoming numb in order to survive it.  For the witch Macha this means turning people to stone to take away their pain.  In this, she thinks she is doing them a favor.

It is not an uplifting story.  Hankies and tissues will be required.

This was a great story about how a family deals with difficulties many families face today.  Not only does it explore the trials of being a parent, but also the responsibilities the older sibling has of taking care of his younger sister.  I loved the supernatural environment in the movie that at times reminded me of The Secret of Kells and Spirited Away.  I would recommend this movie to a person of any age looking to go on an adventure!

Another brilliant film from Tomm Moore--puts most animated children's films to shame with fearless, complex storytelling rooted in Irish mythology and folklore. I say fearless because it traffics in complex emotions and has the courage to believe that children are sophisticated enough to follow along. SECRET OF KELLS is the first movie from Moore, and also not to be missed. Couldn't come any more highly recommended.

Pay no mind to the reviews from people who couldn't watch more than 10 minutes into Song of the Sea. This is truly an incredible film that deserves your attention as well as your praise. It's been awhile since a movie has reached out to me like this one has, between the great voice acting, the beautiful soundtrack, the unique animation, this film had me captivated from start to finish. Please do not be dissuaded by parents whose reviews are based solely on the first few minutes of this film; it is a fantastically touching film for any age group and I'd recommend any and everyone I know to watch it.

I am very disappointed after watching this movie with my two kids they both started crying and my boy was upset for days at the thought of his mom just leaving him and throwing herself into the sea.  Not a good story line in any way for the age group watching this stuff.  The school called and said they were concerned about my son.  He is a well rounded good kid with a great personality and no worries.  He asked multiple times if his mom was ok and kept asking them if she was picking him up and if they were very sure of it(because he kept thinking "what if").  I know what they tried to do in the movie and I respect neat art in kids movies.  But it was disturbing on multiple subjects.  I don't really write reviews but I felt strongly enough about this that I thought I should put on my 2 cents against all the positive reviews this thing got.

Great and artistic story.  A little dark and complex, not like Disney fluff at all.  My almost 4 year old daughter and I watched it curled up together--she is "artistically sensitive" and started to watch it alone another time but found it too scary.  I'm pretty sure it's the darker hued colors and slower pace, etc. that evoked the feelings in her.  She's a child that will hide behind curtains or what have you when emotive classical music is playing because it touches her and she needs help processing so perhaps others will feel differently. Anyway, very good but I'd be prepared to discuss the complexity with the little ones :).

This movie is my favorite movie to watch once in a while when it's the end of the day, I've nothing else to do, and I just want to relax. Also, props for Irish culture! My favorite kid's movie. So refreshing to watch a compelling movie that doesn't rely on sexist, classist tropes. I also love that the ending is complex; the story lines are resolved yet not in an artificial way. The characters have competing needs and the viewer is left to ponder that life is beautiful but not perfect. Heads up: for sensitive kiddos, there are a few tense/scary parts. No blood or violence, but there are some slightly spooky bits and a climax where there main characters face another character with magical powers.
Fantastic art and enjoyable story, recommended family production.

I stumbled upon this movie one morning when I wanted to put something on for my three year olds when I was too tired to do anything other than lie on the couch like a sloth. I'm so glad I did, though, because this movie is seriously gorgeous. The animation style and music are beautiful and haunting all at once. The story is deep, but it had an old school fairy tale style that so many movies are lacking these days. The ending had me sobbing like a baby, though, so if you're a crier (which, come on, you're probably a mom so you probably are, haha) be prepared for that. Oh, and if you're sitting there wondering why the dad's voice sounds so darn familiar it's because he's Mad Eye Moody in Harry Potter!
Overall, I love this movie. I've made my kids watch it again multiple times and my husband has even been roped into the affair. I can totally understand why this has been nominated for so many awards.

Song of the Sea is a precious, childhood Fairy Tale for all ages. It speaks heavily to the beauty of Ireland's Cultural and Magical Heritage. The art of the voice actors combined with the art of the animation fuse together to create a living portrait of awe-inspiring beauty that enchants the heart and fills the soul. I hope to see more beautiful stories like Song of the Sea and The Secret of Kels.

This is a magical little gem of a film that is simultaneously charming, sweet, and sad. The stylized animation adds to the enchantment, reminiscent of Rawle's other well known film, The Secret of Kells. The music, the voice actors, and the story combined to create a wonderful experience that was enjoyed by both the children and adults in our family.

Charming from beginning to end. . ."Song of the Sea" is a movie to be enjoyed by parents and children. The animation style is unique and lovely. I even dreamed of the sea swirls that night. The accompanying music is original and touching. Though I can't understand Gaelic, it was easy to know what the songs meant. I've watched this movie twice, once in a local theatre, then on my computer with Amazon prime. I highly recommend it for an evening's entertainment with kids, and grandkids, too.

The first time I watched this movie with my two children (3 and 7), I thought it might have been too slow paced and the concepts would go over their heads. However, they loved it. My children hardly sit still, normally, but for this movie that sat engulfed in each scene.

The animation is beautiful, it reminded me of an old children's book come to life. The colors are not as bright as a Disney movie but it did seem to have this calming effect. Each scene had its own magical essence to it. As an artist, I, myself, enjoyed the stylized animation.

The story admittedly is much slower pace than the animated movies from the US, but depending on the child, it is still very entertaining. Some concepts may not be understood by some children, but my children did seem to understand the main storyline. Afterward, my 3-year-old kept asking if my hair will turn white and if I will turn into a seal.

A contender for greatest film of all time. Look at the negative reviews. You will notice the one complaint is that their kids didn't like it. I admit that this movie is not primarily for kids. It is primarily for adults. Some mature or intelligent kids will be able to appreciate it's greatness. But you shouldn't expect this to be in the same category as, say, Pixar's Planes. It's not a babysitting movie. It's not a song and dance movie. It's a heavy and beautiful movie about death and loss and pain and coping with that pain, overcoming it, and finding happiness again. Also, selkies.

Song of the Sea was a great movie about a brother's (with some help from their brave dog) journey to help his sister acheive what she was destined to do.  Along the way he is reminded just what it is supposed to mean to be a big brother, something that he has since forgotten since a tragic loss in his life.  If you like any Studio Ghibli film or any film that gives you the feeling that you just watched a good purposeful film, then Song of the Sea won't disappoint you.  The artwork is great, and the film keeps you at the edge of your seat near the end.  Really loved it! Song of the Sea will definitely be a film I would add to my collection for my children.

I did find the production company's website, (Gkids.com) and see there are other movies that promise to be as unique and beautiful as this one. I'm so glad we happened upon this movie.

I loved the ethereal, dream like aesthetic that complements the children's socio-emotional  journey.  Concepts are hinted at through colors patterns and song, which beautifully characterizes the changes that shape the experiences that children overcome throughout childhood. It is such a sobering tale of siblings emerging from their own egocentric perspectives of their existence and coming to see themselves within the context of their broader reality. The mystical elements of the story remind us all that there are things beyond our control that shapes who we are, and accepting this will help us to appreciate the magic that life inherently is!

It is an animated tale of Irish folklore. The images are lyrical and compelling, and the music is hauntingly Irish, and the story is multi-layered and intriguing.

Beautifully animated Irish tale.  This is a wonderful, bitter-sweet story that blends the world of fantastical creatures of Irish folklore with a few of the realities of modern life.  The gorgeous art work and haunting music set the stage for a deeply emotive story of an angry young boy, his broken father and speechless sister that are forever changed as they are thrown into the intersection of a dying world of fairie magic with their own lives marked by momentous personal losses.  This is ultimately an uplifting tale of shifting one's perspective, courage, sacrifice and the power of love.

I wish I could give 10 stars.  Or 100.  This is the one of the greatest movies I have seen in a long time.  It's truly mesmerizing, richly beautiful, a story with deep mythological roots and near-perfect execution.  The story line is deep enough for any adult, yet it is presented in such a way that my 5-year-old can't stop watching it.  The music is brilliant and memorable, and it presents so many meaningful life lessons that my daughter and I often talk about elements of the movie and their connection with real life.  Can you tell I liked it?  Highly recommended is an understatement.

I saw this in a store and saw that it was recently added as a prime video option and decided to give it a try. I'm so glad that I did! This movie is very unique and very entertaining to watch. It seems to be an Irish fable, with Gaelic songs and Irish imagery. It's the story of a young couple with their young son. The mother is very pregnant and sharing stories, songs and gifts with him. Suddenly, the story jumps ahead several years where the family has drastically changed. The mother is gone, the little boy is now around 9 and his sister, the spitting image of her mother, is about 6. The father is in a great state of grief which initiates his mother visiting and taking the children to live with her for their safety. This is where the story follows the 2 children on a magical adventure to find the truth of their family while trying to get back to their home. The story is very unique and very well told.  You will not be disappointed!

Beautiful, and amazing. It's so wonderful. I don't know what exactly it reminds me of but there's movies I'd watch as a child of the 90s that could inspire awe and wonder; this seems like a modern-day version capable of bringing about that same sense of awe and wonder.

Beautiful tale! My 8 year old daughter and I were both in tears by the end. The music and animation made it obvious why it has won numerous awards including an Oscar, Annie, etc. If you are interested in discussing the Irish folklore, you may want to make a trip to your local library. It sparked several conversations in our house.

***Spoilers below***

It is implied that the mom dies at the beginning. She makes a reappearance (she's a selkie), but does not stay with her husband and children at end of the story (make your own conclusions: is she really dead? Does she have to remain a selkie?) Be aware you may have lots to explain to young ones (e.g. my 5 year old).

For those of us who are awed by artistic animation, this is a must-see creation. It's a wholly charming, whimsical, and delightfully rendered film for all ages! I liked "The Secret of Kells". I am enchanted by "Song of the Sea". There is little armed warfare in "Song" (none, if beaks are not considered weapons), so small children may find the story less scary. There are beautiful blended colors and some lilting Irish music; there are panoramic visions of the land and magical undersea views. A few references are made to the films of Miyazaki, appropriately, but this animated story is a most original rendering of the ancient Celtic myth of the selkie.

As mellow as a dram of Irish single-malt, and as charming as an Irish countryside, Song of the Sea deserves its nomination for an Academy Award. The story, about selkies and over-protection, serves the picture but the art direction and animation style soar above other studios efforts. The character design spans semi-realistic to fantasy. The attention to character detail infuses life into the movie. The background art deserves a gallery exhibit of its own.
View this animation masterpiece with your irony/cynicism switch off and you will be transported to a fascinating, wondrous world of creatures better than ourselves.

Just watched Song of the Sea, an animated film that followed up Secret of Kells' beautiful success. It's basically everything that Ponyo (directed by Miyazaki) should have been, and wasn't - and more beautifully animated. It isn't quite as strong a story as Secret of Kells, partially because it isn't based on true history, but what it lacks in story, it more than makes up for with the sheer joy of beautiful drawings, the kind that make you gasp and pause the movie so you can admire the picture. Well worth the watch, and I'll be returning many times to this gem of a movie.

As a parent of a very active and bright 4 year old, I'm always on the hunt for good quality, thought provoking programming. I stumbled across Song of the Sea and thought it looked intriguing. Boy was I shocked.  This movie is probably one of the best we have seen as a family this year.  The storyline is simply enchanting, the illustrations and animation look like they came out of some other world - traditional Hand- drawn, which is what we don't see much of anymore since the dawn of CGI. Anyway, I whole heartedly recommend this charming tale to anyone looking for a unique movie to watch.

I love Pixar and Disney, but once you've seen all of the movies appropriate for young children, it's agonizing sitting through them over and over. My 5 year olds asked for it over and over. Highly recommended.

It is amazing how much this movie does with classic animation techniques. The whole film is medicine for the eyes. The complex portrayals of Saoirse (the half human, half selkie) and her brother Ben go beyond the usual representation of children in animated movies. This is a wonderful movie for both children and adults.

From the very talented group behind Secret of Kells, The Breadwinner, Anam an Amhrain, and Puffin Rock (Cartoon Saloon), Song of the Sea is a wistful and decidedly mythical tale about two siblings embarking on a journey filled - just below the surface - with legends, magic, and mystery. The movie is quiet and earnest, and more of the story is told through looks and lack of dialogue than most children's films, which is a pleasant refrain from the norm. Parents and children alike will enjoy the larger-than-life symbology that the film deftly maneuvers.

The art style is beautiful and the fluid animation is wonderful to behold, and both translate nicely to quiet, still scenes and action packed encounters. Each scene is filled to burst with detail but it's never pointed out, allowing the viewer to steep in a world that feels very much a real place, even while we watch faeries turn to stone. In the end, the movie is about loss and overcoming it, and how far we're willing to go for the ones that we love. I whole-heartily recommend this to anyone.

This is an artwork gem. Not only is the animation stylish and beautiful, it is filled with Celtic imagery and magic.  I was very impressed with the consistency od the forms in this film, as well as the atmospheric quality of the animation. The artwork is beautiful, imaginative, spot on.  The characterizations are also perfect; the older brother, Ben, is a nearly perfect study of an exasperated older sibling.  The Celtic mythology is fun and tells a touching tale. Only small knitpick is that the tale gets a bit confusing towards the end; there are many threads to tie up.  Still, this is a keeper, I recommend it to visual artists as inspiration.

i don't particularly know much about irish culture and folklore, so i can't speak to the adherence of any fairy tales or bedtime stories, but man this is a good one.
the story opens with a very unique style of animation, and i thought, "okay, this looks good. it's probably a flashback or something and we'll just jump into cgi after one of the parents dies and they're set on their quest." well, i was only half right. one of the parents does die, but the animation stays the same. it's very refreshing to see an animated film that's hand-drawn, or at least sticks with the style. it's gorgeous to look at. in a way it resembles something like what a talented child might illustrate, trying to recall a faint dream or a whimsical fantasy. it's a touch of the daydreams of bridge to terabithia and a bit of ponyo.
for a kid's story, it's simple enough, but man does it do it well. it seeks to meld a mythical world with the parallels of modern day correlations, as though it's a child interpreting events around them. and the music is as creative and just as whimsical as the animation. it's like coraline but not as creepy.
this is definitely worth a watch, not just children but children of all ages.

An intriguing tale based on Irish legend and lore; follow two children as they are forced from their childhood home in a lighthouse to live in the city with their grandmother.  Escaping in the middle of the night, the two find themselves being pursued by owls who are controlled by a misguided witch who is trying to steal all emotion from the world.  However, the two also learn the truth behind their long lost mother and of how the youngest, a girl named Saoirse, is also destined to follow in her mother's footsteps unless she should chooses otherwise.

I can't express enough how much I love this movie. The kids love it as well, but I think I may love it more. Other reviews talk of what it's about, a selkie girl and a journey her brother takes her on to help her become who she is and keep alive the magic of the stories they grew up with. But there's such emotion in this movie that cannot truly be captured with words. The family is torn apart when they lose their mother, and with their fathers grief, the children are left to fend for themselves. The kids are sent to live with their grandmother and only when trying to run away home, does the adventure start for them. The beginning shows a grieving, almost neglectful father, a little boy who's angry at the world and his sister. And a little girl who's desperate for love and the acceptance of her brother. As the story goes on, the boy becomes less angry, less resentful, and more loving toward his sister. He begins to understand that nothing that happened in their lives was ever her fault, and becomes her leader, her protector and her support system. Characters in the movie mirror each other. The grieving giant turned to stone mirrors their father, and the owl witch mirrors their grandmother, only trying to help but hurting everyone in the process. It ends in a happy way for all, and God bless you if you don't shed a tear.

Song of the Sea is a G-rated animated fantasy based on an Irish myth, but don't let the G-rating or the fantasy descriptives fool you into thinking the movie doesn't deal with real drama and real life emotions. Unlike so many other G-rated kids' fantasies, particularly the ones that come out of Hollywood -- and, believe me, I do like those, some of them quite a bit (Robots, Wall-E, etc) -- Song of the Sea doesn't fall back on cliches or formulae. It isn't afraid to get deeper into a kid's head. While the delivery vehicle is one of Earth-bound spirits and their savior child born to one of their own, the story follows a path of loss, fear, misdirected anger, despair, illness, and, ultimately, understanding, sacrifice and heroics.

I watched this with my eight year old granddaughter, and she was mesmerized. After the movie, we had a chance to talk about how one deals with being sad. Pretty heavy stuff for an eight year old, but the movie made the conversation easier.

Technically, the movie is beautiful. It's artful and visually inventive. It looks hand drawn.

The movie has some very sad and anxiety-producing undertones. However, it's mostly this incredible adventure that this little girl and her older brother find themselves on; it's an adventure made more exciting by the real-life consequences of failing to succeed.

There's an old meme in filmmaking. "What's the character's motivation?" Producers, directors, writers, actors, will ask this question from time to time. It's so cliche it's become kind of a joke. However, it's the mark of a good script when the characters within are clearly defined by what they want.

In Song of the Sea, every character is clearly defined by what they want or need. Their motives are clear, and even more interesting, they're very different.

Even as the movie starts it's drawing you in with the charming, no muss no fuss artwork that is both comforting, and calming as you are taken through worlds of color and somber tones. The Music is Celtic and so stirringly beautiful that it moves you through various parts of the movie so that each scene is perfect.

Over all? I can not recommend this movie enough. Five stars is not high enough rating for the wonderful masterpiece this movie is. Please don't pass this up like we did for a while, truly, it's one of our favorites now.

This may be the most beautiful animated film ever made. Yes there are many that could rival it, and you could make a strong argument for Snow White, Sleeping Beauty, Beauty and the Beast, Finding Nemo, and of course, virtually every Studio Ghibli film ever made. And I place particular emphasis on that last comparison because Spirited Away changed how I viewed animated films, introducing me to Hayao Miyazaki and being the one animated film I truly became obsessed with. It was the music and the colors and the fantastical story and the larger-than-life characters all set to a highly stylized vision that immersed me in Japanese culture. SONG OF THE SEA is all of this for Irish culture, and perhaps more. It's warmer and more professional than director Tomm Moore's debut film, The Secret of Kells, and takes his Celtic-based visuals to a new level. They're so stunning they are nothing short of brilliant; a true work of art. I can count on one hand how many times a film has made me cry, and the final scene left me weeping. It was the culmination of having seen and heard and felt such a complete masterpiece. Even as Studio Ghibli looks to close with Miyazaki's retirement, Moore's studio Cartoon Saloon is brighter than the sun.

Beautiful illustrations, enchanting story- so different than everything else out there these days.  No violence, no guns, all magic and fantasy.  My five year old son and I loved it.  And he gets pretty scared by a lot of "bad guys" in other "kids" movies, but this didn't have anything for him to be scared of.  The music is great as well.

This movie was simply spectacular. Mythical. Emotionally deep. The story of two Irish children living in an isolated -- though idyllic -- light house on the coast. Their grandmother takes them from their father to have a better life in the city. They long for their spiritual ties to the sea and make their way back.
Such a cute movie with beautiful and an unusual artwork - my children loved the deeper message of learning to face your emotions conquer life's problems.

Animated or not, this is one top of my favorite ones (esp the art and the direction)!

The beauty of this is so rich it is actually tangible-I felt like it was seeping into me and moving me.  I have not watched a movie in many years--am so glad I broke my "fast" with something this exquisite.  Also the layered messages struck home for me--the ways in which so many of us have had our true nature taken from us or have tried to dull the pain by becoming hard.  This film works to put one back in touch with that which is lost or numb.  My thanks to the makers of it.

It's been a while since I've come across such a beautiful film. The story takes me back to childhood fairy tales and myths: the message of love, simple yet powerful; the grand adventure, perilous yet magical; the bitter-sweet finale, makes you laugh and makes you cry. And all of this is brought to life by the most stunning animation imaginable: every frame seems to come straight out of an artistic masterpiece. I am truly enchanted by this wonderful production. Thank you, film-makers, for showing all that is true and beautiful in a seemingly cold and unfeeling world.

A gorgeous film, with lovely music and evocative drawings. Tells a story of sibling relations and complex family dynamics against the backdrop of the Irish legend of the selkie that is highly accessible to children but does not pander to them. The film has beautifully rendered landscapes and oceanscapes, as well as brief but incisive visual commentary on the stifling alienation of urban life. In many ways, the plot is similar to the much-heralded, but far less interesting "Inside Out" -- both films revolve around children dealing with difficult emotions and the importance of acknowledging fear, anger, and sorrow.  Compared to "Song of the Sea," however, the colors and graphics of "Inside Out" are garish and facile, and the story is low-stakes and uncompelling.  "Song of the Sea," by contrast, has real moments of anxiety, relief, and beauty, as well as intriguing characters and subtle environmental commentary. The creators of "Song of the Sea" also made "The Secret of Kells," which my kids and I also love and highly recommend.

So my kid was 20 months when she first saw this.  Granted, she probably has a little bit of a longer attention span than some her age, but, it's now been requested by her, and watched, at least 30 more times, and it's only been a month or so.  Maybe 5 weeks?  And as an adult who grew up with hand-drawn Disney stuff and the subsequent 3D/CGI movies over the last ~15 years, this movie is one of the best I've seen in AGES, both for the story and the animation/beauty.  It's fantastic.  I've watched it at least 8 times and even listen to the main theme song on a regular basis, and got it on a usb drive for my daughter to listen.  She frequently says "Song Sea" as soon as we get in the car.  I'm just saying, this movie is amazing.  It has some dark tones to it.  There are some heavy subjects, but, it's super all around.  I wish I could give it 10 stars.

One of the best movies I've seen in a long time.

For an animated feature, this is a compelling and enchanting movie that beautifully and touchingly weaves together tales of
Irish folklore with the more human story of a lighthouse keeper trying to keep his family together as a single parent.  The melding of
the fantastic with the mundane occurs so seemingly effortlessly that the viewer is taken into a story that seems real and true despite
the obvious homage to Irish fairy tales.  The artwork is haunting and stunning, with brilliant transitions from reality to fantasy and back that make this film a marvelous entertainment that anyone should enjoy.

This is a wonderful story, well told. It is the story of a little girl who is a silky, a female seal appearing in a human body.  Her mother was a silky as well, and disappeared from her husband and children when the little girl was born. The father wants to prevent his daughter from discovering the truth and going back to her seal heritage, and his son resents the sister he promised his mother to protect. When the children are sent inland to stay with their grandmother, a little girl needs the help of her brother to return her to the sea if she is to live.

The art was beautiful. I really wanted to like this movie. And I would have liked it if the writers had taken time to make the plot make sense. But no. They didn't. If Ben's mom was a selkie and a selkie needed to sing the magic selkie song to free all of the magical creatures, why didn't Ben's mom sing the song to begin with? And speaking of the mom, why did she have to leave her children? The movie never tells us. And then she just shows back up after years and is going to take her daughter and she doesn't say anything to her son and husband until they say, "Please don't take her, she's all we've got." (Um, you have each other.) I think they would have said, "Why did you leave us?" She tells them she has to leave today, but again, we're given no explanation as to why all the magical creatures have to leave. What a great message for children. Sometimes your parents just leave you for no reason.

Also, why wasn't Ben half selkie since his mom was a selkie? Are only girls selkies? Do you have to be born in the water to be a selkie? Either of these explanations might be a part of selkie mythology, but the writers shouldn't just assume the audience is going to know these details. Ben never asks these questions and the movie doesn't explain.

Why didn't Ben's sister speak until the climax of the movie? Again we don't know.

And then there's the grandmother. She takes the children so they'll be safer, sends them to their room in the middle of the day and then apparently doesn't check on them again. She wakes up that night and, again for no apparent reason says, "The children are gone!" Well, maybe she would have realized this earlier if she'd checked on them before she went to bed.

It wouldn't have taken much time for the writers to throw in some explanations to these issues, but they didn't.

This is a fabulous film.  If anything, it is stronger than Moore's _Secret of Kells_.  That may be an unfair comparison because each film is directed at, and accomplishes different things.  With_Song of the Sea_ you get jaw-dropping, beautiful animation (especially the backgrounds and sets), you get witty dialogue, mystery, and ultimately something very deep.  The modern translation of traditional Irish folk culture is impeccable.  The captured sense of childhood (a strength shared with _Kells_) should be an object lesson to every parent--think hard and remember the depth of passion, the vision, and the powerful love that defined your childhood worldview.  Remember it and honor it in your own kids.  Watch this, whether you have kids or not.  In the end, it is a beautiful and fanciful exploration of how mythology unlocks deeply true things about being human.

I watched this movie to see if it would be a good movie for my children to watch. While the themes are a bit overwhelming for my 3- and 6-year-old, I cannot say enough good about this incredible movie. It is a movie I will absolutely watch again. The animation is the best I have seen, the story is enchanting and heartfelt, and the voices are perfection. I'm an adult who is kind of weary of the over-sexualized and overly violent movies made for "grown ups" these days. It is refreshing to have a story told in such beauty and grace that imparts significant meaning. This is a re-watchable movie that is quite memorable. Highly, highly recommended.

Later, she asked me about how they drew so well and definitely wanted to emulate some of their techniques.  The closing credits that showed some of the early artwork and animation were a real treat.  Highly recommend to anyone!

I also really love the idea of engaging stories that don't have true villains, like Kiki's Delivery Service. This film is a good example of that.

I am a big fan of Miyazaki and Studio Ghibli. "Song of the Sea" has the same sort of appeal for me as Miyazaki movies do, including excellence of story, artistry, and music. This recent (11-08-2015) review in The Guardian accurately represents the way I feel about "Song of the Sea":

"Irish animator Tomm Moore nabbed an underdog Oscar nomination this year for his crystal-delicate Celtic fable Song of the Sea (Studiocanal, PG); his loss to the slick Disney mechanics of Big Hero 6 was as inevitable as it was unjust, but his lovely, lawn-lush vision may just become a whispered word-of-mouth classic. Moore understands children intuitively enough not to pacify or patronise them: as the film follows two young siblings  one human, one selkie  as they find their way home after being brusquely moved to Dublin, theres a very real sense of sadness and insecurity coursing through its fantastically imagined twist on folklore, drawn as though refracted through stained glass. Though its steeped in the imagery and mythology of its region, there are welcome echoes of the already missed Studio Ghibli here."

http://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/nov/08/spy-song-of-sea-self-less-dvd-revew

I watched this on my own, without the kids. But I just adored it, the art, the music, their voices- it was all sweet and lovingly done. The family dynamics, sadness, and imagery all combined to make this a wonderful, delightful treat for the eyes. The brother and sister dynamics felt realistic, and Ben's pain was always there, but it added to the story, rather than serving as an annoying plot device. Seirsa (sp?) was so complex and really developed as a character. Poor little girl. The grandmother is underrated- she really did try so hard, and received so much abuse for it. Overall I really loved how the siblings worked together for their common goal, and how pain and feelings were used to develop the story, rather than just serve as distractions. I felt very pleased and satisfied with the ending, no baring problems became clear to me. Would definitely recommend for a night in, or for family.

This movie stirred up so many feelings in me over the course of an hour and a half that by the end I was an emotional cocktail. The art is drop dead gorgeous and if I wasn't so enraptured by the movie itself, I could spend hours just staring at the flawless backgrounds and seamless animation. Every character is lovable in their own way and each has their very own method to capturing your heart in the end. Plot was very moving and wasn't rushed at all, the pacing leaves you feeling as excited and anxious as the characters do while the story unfolds. I will admit, I cried during this movie. It gets very emotional at certain parts while still managing to make you feel both excited and happy.

All in All, a near perfect movie. You won't regret watching it!

Breathtakingly beautiful artwork, characters and story. Immediately got to my "top 10 favorite cartoons ever" list, sitting right next to Spirited Away.  Some may call it too slow, abstract, psychedelic or sad, I say they don't understand what real art is in animation.

I absolutely loved the secret of kells, so when I found out they made this movie too, I had to see it. Like The Secret of Kells, the visuals in this movie absolutely blew me away  every single frame was a breathtaking work of art. Im a huge fan of fairytales, folklore and mythology, so it was really interesting to hear about a mythological creature Id never heard of before. Selkies seem to be the Irish take on mermaids women who are able to turn into seals with the help of a magical sealskin coat.

Overall I really liked this movie. I didn't like the storyline quite as much as The Secret of Kells, but the artwork and uniqueness of the tale made up for it. I would definitely recommend this movie to adults and children alike!

This is an amazing movie. I found it the other night, and I thought I would watch a bit before bed. I ended up watching the entire thing because I just couldn't stop. The animation is different than what I am used to, but it was very pleasant and detailed. It is nice to know that there are still clean, family-friendly movies out there. This movie doesn't rely on over-the-kids-head sort of jokes and innuendo. The magic and wonder of the story sells itself without catering to two different audiences at once. If you are looking for a movie you and your kids will enjoy, this is it. Especially if you are concerned about the adult content slipped into so many modern children's shows, as this has none. It is a truly magical film, capable of capturing the interest of all ages. Come prepared to watch the entire movie, you might not be able to turn away!

Excellent family movie and a fun and beautiful look into Irish mythology

With an imaginative storyline of Irish folklore and beautiful imagery, this movie has taken over my top spot in favorite animated films.

Full disclosure, I cry through 75% of this movie. Not necessarily out of sadness, but out of sheer emotional attachment to the characters and their respective journeys through magical, transformative events. It is about family bonds, love, loyalty, and a little girl who is capable of freeing the spirit world from their purgatory of sadness. It has a touches of Studio Ghibli's Ponyo, but Song of the Sea is a deeper web of storytelling, and hits heavier subjects like death and depression, with an underlying message about bottling up negative feelings. The bittersweet nature of the film is the crux of the story; it never remains stagnant or black and white, but ebbs and flows in an abyss where reality and metaphors become one.

If you are banging your head against the wall because your kid wants to watch Barbie Fairytopia Mermaidia for the 937th time, this will be the cure for what ails you.

I must say, this was an excellent film from every perspective.  The only reason it didn't get five stars was the slow start.  Yes, it had a slow start, but it drew me in once it really got into the plot.  And I also like that unlike a lot of movies that feature magical creatures, this one wasn't about them fighting...  Per se.  There wasn't a huge amount of magical combat.

Although the magical creatures were fighting for the Selkie, it was more about Saoirse's and Dan's relationship, and how Dan went from resenting Saoirse to loving her and dreading the moment when she had to leave, it was a beautiful film about a beautiful subject.  The simple art style was also nice.  There weren't complexly drawn characters in it, but that also kept the viewer from being distracted from the point of the film.  So kudos.

Overall, I'd say that this film really did a great job, and I'd recommend it to anyone who doesn't mind a slightly slow start.

  -> the profound sound quality which makes your ears filled with elixered symphonous music.
  -> a great script which has captured all the necessary ingredients of the original skandinavian folk tale.
  -> brings all the old nostalgic moments of your child hood days where we use to live in our dream lands after reading a story/ folk tale.

This was such a neat movie, I really didn't expect to like it much at all- seeing that it was nominated for an Academy Award drew me to it, but I also half expected it to be too artsy or weird. The animation, which I've read is hand drawn, is phenomenal! There is such a nice flow of the artwork, it intertwined beautifully with the storyline throughout the movie. The story itself is very unique in that it is based on a figure from Irish Folklore, a Selkie, which is a seal that can live as a human. Sounds weird, but it's really interesting and I was so engaged in this story (much more than my distracted 11 month old) that it was the equivalent of reading a book you can't put down. The artwork gave the movie a really magic feel, I actually can't wait to watch it again. And if for some reason it was not free with my Prime membership, I would buy this movie. It was really great!

I enjoyed Song of the Sea from the very start. I have over a quarter Celtic blood and I am fond of the Scotish (?) legend of Silkies being seals that can become human when the reach dry land (they pronounced it Selkies in the film.) The animation and art, plus the mythology surrounding the subject are interesting enough, but the story line of an older child resenting the arrival of a new younger sibling also struck a chord with me... oh yes and there's lovely music too! This seems a children's movie but the grownup in me enjoyed it too.

What would you give up to be free of heartbreak--or to protect your children from pain?  That dilemma is one that plagues mythological creatures from centuries past and modern man alike in this modern day retelling of mythological adventures.

Please watch "Song of the Sea;" I recommend it highly to young or old!  Poignant, relatable, beautiful.  I kept wanting to pause each scene to look at the gorgeous illustration. Deceptively simple use of line and animation in many places would morph into intensely rich color palettes and flowing movement.  I loved the aesthetic,the story, the music.

Complete with frightening adventures and mystically wondrous elements, this gorgeous story will delight and touch your heart.  And anyone who has been a sibling will relate to the main characters. Ostensibly a story for children, I was captivated.

I was very pleased with this movie. My toddler was engaged, my girlfriend was engaged, I was engaged. Song of the Sea employs a beautiful, fanciful story that illustrates and challenges a number of family and sibling dynamics that just about everyone can relate to, especially parents. This movie touched on nearly every emotion and kept my whole family wondering what oils happen next. Song of the Sea has easily jumped up to one of our family favorites. I highly recommend this movie to anyone and everyone, but especially to parents with young children.

Much better than the director's other animated movie, the Secret of Kells.  I don't know if it has the repeat watchability of the obvious comparison and no doubt inspiration, Hayao Miyazaki's 'My Neighbor Totoro'  (what could??), but it has a sustained plot that 95% of Miyazaki's movies DON'T have.  (Ahem Spirited Away, and every other HM movie not NMT.)  The animation and overall painting of the characters and especially sets are amazing.  Only complaint  (SPOILER):  they younger sister is by far the stronger of the two (three, sorry, forgot dog) protagonists, and dominates the first half;  but by the latter half she has become merely a prop for her bother's story.  However, her brother's journey is ultimately rewarding, so, forgiven.

I liked the Secret of Kells but this movie really blew me away. The combination of the autumnal modern day setting intertwined with Celtic mythology was just breathtaking. On the surface, the story is about the legendary selkie, but there's so much more to this tale in terms of the other myths it draws upon and the very realistic little family at its center. A beautiful story of wonder, grief, independence, dysfunction and ultimately, love, this movie is on the shelf with my all-time favorite animations. If you're a fan of Coraline, Fantastic Mr. Fox and Miyazaki films, you'll certainly enjoy this movie.

Tom Moore is an Irish Hayao Miyazaki. song of the Sea incorporates Celtic art to tell a beautiful story that reads like folklore. I'm not Irish, but if I was, I would be immensely proud of Moore after Secret of Kells and now this immensely imaginative gem that is Song of the Sea.

Just finished watching "Song Of The Sea" released by Universal.
How this wonderfully animated story of love lost and rediscovered failed to win the Oscar back in 2014 for best animated feature film is beyond me.
"Song Of The Sea" tells the story of Ben, who holds his baby sister Saoirse responsible for the death of their mother, who he believes died when she gave birth to her.  Only Ben's mother was a Selkie, and Saoirse was the last born of that enchanted race.
To celebrate Saoirse's birthday, their Grandmother comes down from the city to visit the island where their father is the lighthouse keeper.  Ben's resentment of Saoirse creates tension throughout the day, and at nighttime, when everyone is asleep, Saoirse slips into Ben's room and takes the enchanted seashell their mother gave him.  By blowing into the horn, she soon discovers the enchantment which leads her to her seal skin, which her father had hidden away.
An outing in the sea with her seal skin on, leads their Grandmother to take her back to the city; where Ben plots to escape; but soon learns that Saoirse is more than just his baby sister, and if he is to save her and his family; he must put aside his fears and do the one thing he's been afraid of all his life - swim.
At times, the animation almost rivals Studio Giblhi in it's story telling.
STRONGLY RECOMMENED!

I've never written a review before but I'm writing one now because this movie seems to be relatively unknown, and quite honestly it deserves more attention.

Song of the Sea is simply one of the best animated films I've ever seen. The animation is stunning, albeit not what you'd expect from a 2014 film, it is still beautiful and it absolutely works. The movie is based off of an Irish legend of the selkie, which I honestly had no idea about before watching this film but you don't have to understand the legend to understand this film, the story is simple enough anyone can understand and enjoy it! Nothing complex about this film, both kids and adults can enjoy it. The music as well is phenomenal, it is absolutely beautiful from start to finish. I don't feel I need to say more (As I won't go into movie plot details), other than just watch this film already! You won't regret it!

Song of the Sea is an absolutely gorgeous animated film that is equally enchanting, adorable, and heartbreaking.

I remember when Big Hero 6 won the 2015 Oscar for Best Animated Film, and I remember there was an overwhelming gnashing of teeth from people who were all, "What even? It wasn't that good!" and I, not having seen Song of the Sea (or Boxtrolls, or Kaguya), was thinking that they were a bunch of sore losers and that Big Hero 6, even with its flaws, was a great movie with fun characters, quick plot, and good lessons, and deserved the win.

After I watched Song of the Sea, I found myself in the camp of teeth gnashers. It's not that Big Hero 6 isn't a good movie, Song of the Sea is simply a BETTER one.

The same storybook style that was so intriguing in the Secret of the Kells has evolved into something transcendent in Song of the Sea. The characters are very relatable even if you are not familiar with the Irish backdrop and the inheritance of Irish folklore that runs through this film's veins (heaven knows I was a bit lost with all that talk of Tir Na Nog and giants and fairies). The main character is a little boy who loses his mother on the night his sister is born. The loss breaks his father and induces the paternal grandmother to try and get the kids to stay with her, in the city, instead of on their little lighthouse island. We see how much the little boy resents his sister, and though it's clear that it's unjustified--she's a sweet, curious, and quiet little girl--we still can't help but sympathize with him a bit. This starting point makes his subsequent physical journey as he tries to get back to his lighthouse home from his grandma's house in the city, and the emotional growth as he finally confronts the wounds in his heart and tries to find closure to a tragedy, all the more substantial. You see real character development, and it happens in such a natural, organic way (even with all the fairies and owls about).

Put it this way--the movie's ending is heartbreaking, whether you read too deeply into the symbolism of it or not. But it's also strangely uplifting, as though the whole movie is meant to be heartbreaking, until the very end, when sadness becomes acceptance, and acceptance into joy at a new day.

I would highly recommend this film to both children and adults. I'm not sure who would cry more: mom and dad, or the kids. My husband and I blubbered quite a bit at some points, but it was cathartic in its own way, so I'll consider it a bonus. I fully intend to add this movie to my hardcopy collection; it really is that good. Better than an inflatable robot hero.

This movie is by the creators of "The Secret of Kells" and it shows in similarity of the art work and designs.  It is a lovely piece of animation with a strong story.  Fans of "Kells" will not be disappointed.

No criticism of other animated movies, but a lot of 3-D animation and stop motion animation these days go for realism.  I am thinking of the hair and fur in the How to Train Your Dragon movies and the action sequences in such films as Box Trolls and Kung Fu Panda.  Those are amazing feats of animation and the camera work and craft make you forget this is all hand done.

But Song of the Sea takes a completely different track.  This is clearly 2D style animation, with very stylized characters and settings.  This is a cartoon and it never lets you forget that fact.  But the artwork is so beautifully done and carefully designed that you could take almost any frame of the film and frame it as a picture.  I am thinking specifically of the swirling underwater scenes, the circular designs in the forest and the flying owls, and moments of magic that glisten on the screen.  It is an old fashioned, very painterly approach to the genre that is a great change of pace.

I have said little of the plot, but the old tropes of family love and youthful quest are given a nice spin with the Celtic legend of the selkie that makes this story feel original.  It is not an action packed adventure but it lulls you into a story full of magic and wonder.  It is a type of film that could easily get lost in the shuffle but it reminds you what "old school" animation is still capable of achieving.

I can't say enough good things about this film, although it should probably be noted that it might not appeal to the youngest of kids who probably won't grasp everything the story has to say about loss, grief, and abiding connections both to family and to the natural world (and who also might be bothered by a few mildly scary images). But viewers of any age will marvel at the animation, which will remind you of the minimalistic yet breathtakingly beautiful style of The Secret of Kells, this studio's first feature from 2009. The deceptively simple 2-D animation style and the focus on the children's point-of-view mask deeply resonant themes, and the film displays a very deft understanding of the complex, powerful, sometimes terrifying emotional relationships between parents and children. The easy interweaving of traditional Irish imagery and mythology is an added bonus. Comparisons to the work of Studio Ghibli are very apt; I can't wait to see what this director and production company do next.

If you have seen the Secret of Kells and enjoyed it, then you should definitely see Song of the Sea. The same art style, fantasy meets reality theme, and child perspective is carried over in Song of the Sea. It's nice to see something that while created on computers has a hand-drawn artistic quality to it, that is unlike today's typical polygonal animated fair. At times however this has somewhat of a Studio Ghibli (My Neighbor Totoro, Spirited Away) feel to it. Not only is this a emotional children's movie, it is a nice introduction to Irish folklore and thematically outside of your typical anime or american-made animated film. The characters and their motivations are relatable and believable within the context of the world.

For slightly older children I could see this movie coming off as a little slow as it's not "action packed" and the pacing is even-keeled without a lot of dynamic scenes which may come of as boring. As an adult that enjoys animation and creativity, I loved the plot as well as the aesthetics of the film.

Part culture-promoting modern treatment on Irish folklore, part coming-of-age tale for not one, but two characters, Song of the Sea is a *highly* emotionally manipulative tale with a rich storybook-like presentation and an excellent soundtrack.  The story is at times rushed and nonsensical, and the characters come off as underdeveloped, but it's nice to see a sincere attempt at a bittersweet, original story to contrast with Disney's formulaic, royalty-obsessed drivel.

The Studio Ghibli influence is strong, and the film does little to hide the obvious fact that many Ghibli films had been directly drawn from for inspiration, particularly Ponyo (which was pretty much the source of the story - both films center around a house on a cliff by the sea and a magical girl whose mother is a kind of goddess), but also Spirited Away (lending the witch Yubaba in the form of Maca, with her large-headed bird-like appearance and avian lackeys and similar theme of "alter egos"), and My Neighbor Totoro (whose Cat Bus was split into a normal bus scene and a magical-spirit-dog-powered transportation scene.)

There are some truly cathartic moments - particularly the reawakening of the old "spirits" of folklore at the end - which are only somewhat sullied by a nagging feeling of hollowness to the characters which I'll get to in a second.

The animation, similarly to Ghibli's, is good, but somewhat inconsistent, perhaps taking a page out of the Japanese book of animation production, which prioritizes shots to control workload, conserving extra keyframes and in-between frames to shots where it will count the most.  Sadly, it seems that at certain points, budget or time constraints forced some very rough-looking animation to make it into the final cut in places where it was unfortunately conspicuous.  It's hard not to notice the lack of detail in much of the actual motion of the characters themselves - think of it as TV serial quality animation on steroids - which perhaps was meant to go hand-in-hand with the minimalistic character design - but it does not always service the story as effectively as it should.  Some scenes are done better than others, and it's easy to downplay it for not being up to the level of Disney or Ghibli in terms of attention to detail, but the quality of the animation sits somewhere in the area of "adequate".

Crucial scenes, particularly involving any dialog, are surprisingly abbreviated for an hour-and-a-half-long screenplay, which seems to favor poignant, pretty vignettes over convincing characters.  Some of the worst bits of dialog can be found at the conclusion.  "Saoirse's a selkie?"  "Yeah."  That shot was particularly enraging because the father's response (or lack of one) did nothing to resolve the impenetrable ambiguity of the father's actions up to that point.  The visuals of the film are so lush it sets the viewer up to expect a story that is sophisticated and, one would hope, also accurate in its portrayal of how people would act in this situation.  However there are many, many broadly-stroked exchanges between characters that unfortunately leave all the characters easily-digestible and predictable.  The brother is the most fleshed out of all, but he isn't particularly believable, being more of a cute-ified abstraction of a troubled boy presented at arm's length than a character I could truly believe and relate to.

Ponyo this is not, but for a second outing, it's a remarkable and definitely unforgettable achievement.  This is bound to become a favorite of children all over, while also being well-enjoyed by adults alike.

This has to be one of the most enjoyable animations that I've seen in a long time. A catalogue of memorable Irish tunes and Irish folklore that I recall from my childhood bring a depth of story for me and a feast of imagery and song for my kids. The kids (3yrs and a nearly 2yr old) have been 'singing' the songs for weeks which have fueled many a spontaneous family dance party for us. Not a lot of kids work can bring you to a place of wanting the story to continue or the tune to play one more time, but Song of the Sea has managed to deliver this magical formulae.

During the opening song I immediately recognized the signature of Bruno Coulais from his work on Coraline. The movie drew my wife and I right in and we both thought it reminded of us Neil Gaiman's Mirrormask. An equally enchanting tale told using very artistic methods and music. While Mirrormask may have more in common with Alice in Wonderland, the idea that fantasy and another world can help us understand and work through the difficulties of reality is what they really share.

The animation is so different from anything I've seen.  My husband, our 2 year old and myself, can watch "Song of the Sea" over and over again.  We fell in love with the characters, the music, and the detail of the story.  Its a movie for young and old alike!

In many years I have not seen a movie which has had the same effect on me. Tender, warm, it brings a myth to life through this family. The brother at the beginning of the movie is rough with his sister, perhaps because he thinks she was responsible for the loss of their mother. As the stories progresses his love for his sister shows itself and he risks his life for her.
There are many lessons within the story. One is the confrontation between father and young son when the boy had to disobey his father and dive to find the selkie's skin. Sometimes we find ourselves disagreeing with someone we dearly love and respect, but we need to follow our convictions or we do not grow and will live with eternal regret if we do not act.
The little girl, the selkie, so trusting of her brother and so reliant on him at times. On her life other lives are held in the balance. The scene at the end in which she is allowed to stay with her father, who in such simple words tell her mother 'she is all we have.' And so the little girl stays with her brother and father because she knows there is love there also. I will purchase some copies and give to a few relatives.

The last movie I've seen that had my attention like this was spirited away. I'm surprised I have never heard of this before.

Like this team's previous work, _Secret of Kells_, _Song of the Sea_ is absolutely gorgeous. _Song_ is even cuter than _Secret_, too, with some of the most adorable singing and voice acting. There are distinct resonances with Miyizaki's _Spirited Away_ and _Ponyo_, but this one lies somewhere in between: more accessible to younger viewers than _Spirited Away_, but with more for slightly older kids and adults than _Ponyo_.

I haven't seen Pixar's _Inside Out_ yet, but from what my wife tells me of her two viewings, a major theme is the idea that you can't be any one emotion (Joy, for instance) all the time, and trying to have one emotion all the time is dangerous. Given that, I think _Song of the Sea_ dovetails nicely, as a major theme here is the danger of trying to lock-away, hide from, or (in this case, literally) bottle-up your emotions, positive or negative.

The animation is like nothing else, as are the fairy characters out of Irish mythology. It's absolutely a must-see, and probably a must-own if you have kids.
