SONG OF THE SEA was nominated for BEST ANIMATED FEATURE, 2014. Seeing how it was up against Disney's FROZEN, it never had a chance.

The story is sweet, sad and in a single word, ENCHANTING. The design, artistry and execution of the animation is deeply satisfying in both detail and simplicity. There is nothing Disney-esque about SONG OF THE SEA--nor does it resemble Anime. The music is by composer Bruno Coulais (Coreline, Secret of Krells) and is extraordinary. Some of the images and situations may be too frightening for kids under the age of 5.

In conclusion, this is a world-class animated feature that will engage kids and deeply touch adults. This is a must see--especially if you have Amazon Prime which offers this film for free!

Absolutely beautiful film.  The animation has a unique style that turns minimal geometry into spectacular scenes- it's so strong that it propels Song of the Sea as much as the plot.  The plot and characters were similarly composed: minimal, but so well-done that they become engaging.  The movie honors Irish folklore, but makes it more relatable by choosing a modern setting.  It's extremely rare to find a film that comes together so well.  Everything was well-executed, and I'd recommend it to anyone.

I feel like as Americans we have lost this type of true culture from wherever we may have come from. And the stories that are similar and are "native american" we have stifled. Such a shame. I am happy to be Irish, French, and Cherokee, but I wish I was raised with more of a sense of culture.

This is a lovely film. I took my daughter to see it at an independent movie theater near our home in Western Massachusetts and was excited to see that it was available on Amazon Prime. The beautiful animation is hand drawn and painted over rich watercolor backgrounds. The moving story of a grieving father raising his two children alone in Ireland is steeped in myth and folklore. The accompanying celtic score is serene. My four year old daughter loved this movie and has watched several times with rapt attention as these two children navigate the Irish countryside on a journey of self-discovery that brings them back to their home in a lighthouse overlooking the sea.

Beautiful movie. Up there with Ponyo and Totoro as one of our true favorites for whole family. We must have watched it a dozen times in the first month after first viewing. Didn't know any selkie stories before seeing this. This is much happier than the traditional selkie story, so don't let that dissuade you.

Has a few harrowing parts that upset our 4 yr old boy the first time. Makes mom cry more than kids. More harrowing than Ponyo, less so than Up or Planes. Not harrowing to our 7 and 9 yr old boys, but still captivated.

Let me get this out of the way first.
The visuals were great. I enjoyed this style of drawing and animation. Everything was really cute and pleasing to the eyes.
The sound and music designed were great as well. In essence it was a semi-musical adventure, wear singing was the main topic, without going into a musical (which, this movie greatly benefited from). That really matches the semi-slow pacing of this story as well.
The voice acting... was okay. Though this story was about a song, it really benefited more from its animation than its voice acting or singing, which was quite average.
I was annoyed at the child... but its to be expected, since the plot itself is sort of cliche (big brother hating little sister, then changes). Quite predictable plot really, but that is not what makes it good.
The story itself, along with the sound and music design and the visuals make this a great movie.
And its about a seldom talked about subject in english culture... irish lore. (I think. I don't really know anything about European lore).

So everything goes great until the ending.

***Spoilers***
I don't know if I missed something while watching the movie, but why do they have to leave the world again? Was there a purpose for them leaving? I don't really understand why they had to leave. There was pretty much nothing that touched upon it. So it makes no sense why, in the end, everyone ended up leaving. If its because of some spiritual life force that can't exist in this world, then it would be best to be explained.
Why do the worlds need to be separated? Is this some pre-Korra avatar stuff? Do they die in this world? But it appears that singing solves everything, so all they would need to do is sing every now and then. They had physical bodies before. Wait, does that mean their dead, and are pure spirits?
If that is so, that this ending is kind of depressing. Everyone "died" anyways, despite the daughter's effort to save everyone, so they had to leave anyways, neglecting the whole point of the plot. And they had to leave anyways. Why didn't the mother do this earlier? Clearly she still had her Avatar powers to connect the spirit and material world, thus opening a gate for all the spirits to go in.
And wait, doesn't the daughter need the coat to talk, or did she become pure human, since the coat was destroyed? I missed that part in the story, because I was completely stuck upon wondering why everyone had to leave.
And, why are they dying? Because they are losing their power? I don't really know, its not explained. Why would they come to the human world if they were going to come here knowing that it was a one way street, ending with death, even in their spirit form? That would mean that it wasn't like that before, so what changed since then? Can't they change it back, so that they don't "die" in the material plane?
Do I have to know actual irish lore to understand this? Then I refuse, because such an explanation should be in the story, even if its the mother telling the story to the child.
Uhh.. I don't really understand. Why. Why are the fairies in the human world. Why does the Selkie have to avatar everyone back to the spirit world? And why the hell does the Selkie have to go with them? Because she is their queen? It appears they would still be connected anyways. I mean, her mother probably did the same thing. So does that mean, there is an endless cycle of all the spirits moving to the human world, and the selkie singing them back to the spirit world? What would even be the purpose of doing that? Does that mean this is the last and final time spirits can cross over (because based on the prologue scenes, it seems that they have been doing this for eons)?
These are questions that are never explained, and I would never care to find out the answer to because they were never elaborated in the movie.

tl;dr Aside from a "nitpick" that I consider a major plot failure (or hole as some would call it, but I consider it a failure because how this is answered would completely deny the premise of the story). It was a good movie. Great story (minus some plot), great sound and music design (though the acting was lacking, except for the prologue voice acting), and cute and beautiful visuals and styles. I would recommend this.

We all remember when the nominees for the 2014 Academy Awards were being read off to us and we got to the Animated Film category andno one heard the name The LEGO Movie.  Actually, you may not remember it.  You see, the film was heavily considered the frontrunner to such an extreme that I personally didn't notice the snub until a few minutes later when I was compiling my list of the nominees and I noticed I didn't type The LEGO Movie down in the list.  I did a double take, looked it up, and low and behold, it was indeed snubbed.

Outrage ensued.

I, personally, was pretty upset about it.  I was upset because I had seen three of the actual nominees (How to Train Your Dragon 2, The Boxtrolls and Big Hero 6) and while I liked all of them to a certain extent (some more than others), The LEGO Movie was a notch above the rest.  I was NOT upset because The Tale of the Princess Kaguya and Song of the Sea were nominated.  I had not seen those films, but I had read the raves, and I have no problem with foreign films sneaking in anywhere, so that was not a problem for me at all.  It was the American films I took issue with.

But, a lot of people didn't look at it that way.  Did you happen to read the Brutally Honest Oscar Voters comments from that year.

And I quote:

for that movie not to be in over these two obscure freakin Chinese f***in things that nobody ever freakin saw, that is my biggest b***.

Ignorance people, ignorance.  I absolutely hate ignorance, but when  it comes from your craft then I hate it even more.  These are Oscar voters, which means they work or have worked in the industry.  Have some class.  Honestly, it shows that these voters consider Animated Films to be lesser works that are to be judged by their children (one voter actually stated that she let her children decide the winner) and not judged on the merit of what they contribute as a standalone film, and this is a shame.

Heres the thing; Song of the Sea is a better film than The LEGO Movie.  This isn't a knock on The LEGO Movie a film I found endlessly entertaining and extraordinarily clever, but Song of the Sea is pretty close to absolute perfection and, in a just world, would have won the Oscar (I still haven't seen The Tale of the Princess Kaguya).

Song of the Sea tells the story of Ben, a young boy who loves his mother dearly, but on the eve of his sisters birth his mother disappears in quite the tumultuously mysterious way, and so Ben has grown to nearly despise his younger sister, Saoirse.  But there is something special about Saoirse.  You see, shes the last of the selkies.  If you aren't familiar with selkies, they are basically Irish mermaids, creatures of folklore that are seals who transform into beautiful women.  The film then follows Ben and Saoirse as they journey to undo a curse placed on her people and free them once a for all, in the process saving Saoirses life, as she struggles to survive without her coat (in Irish folklore, a selkie sheds her seal coat when she becomes a human, but needs it in order to survive).

Im personally quite fascinated by selkies.  I love that kind of fairytale, and Ive seen a few wonderful films that have touched upon the subject.  Song of the Sea is the best that Ive seen.  It has such a beautiful way of being both magical in scope and yet so intimate and honest in texture.  The way it touches upon the bitter and consuming aspects of grief is so heartbreaking, whether it be the way that Ben and Saoirses father, Connor, becomes a mere shell of a man in the wake of his wifes disappearance, or the way that it was one mans uncontrollable sadness that caused his mother to curse the land in order to spare him (and herself) the continued grief.  It also shows how grief can be overcome and can be used to make us stronger, to help us love deeper and appreciate what we do have.  And lets not forget the beautiful tale of the bond between siblings here, which is so touching, so moving, so heartwarming.

Not only is Song of the Sea a profound piece of storytelling, but its a visual wonder.  The animated here is truly transfixing, with complex and spellbinding sets and a range of details that light up the screen.  The scope of this animation is astonishing.  And the music, oh the music.  The rich Irish musicality complete with some stunning Original Songs by one of my personal favorite singers, Lisa Hannigan, bring such life, spirit and culture to this brilliant film.

So, The LEGO Movie should have been nominated for the Oscar; no doubt.  Im in agreement with you there.  BUT, it should not have been at the expense of this cinematic wonder.

A gloriously beautiful film. The character animation is not to my taste--highly stylized and super "cute"--but they were still effective and well done, and the background animation was absolutely stunning. The detail, the color, the design--it's all just so beautiful. The story is just as rich and lovely as the artwork, about a broken family, a fabulous dog, and of course a selkie, and the healing she brings to all the characters. The music was beautiful too. Just a gorgeous film. I'll be buying more copies to give as birthday and Christmas gifts.

I thought Song of the Sea was incredible, and at the time I watched the movie at home, my 6-year-old granddaughter saw it in a theater; she detailed the story all the way home with her Mom, who'd not been part of the outing to see the show--a 6 year old understood the story, was able to repeat it, and was captivated by it.

I thought the movie actually could have been shortened down--there were slow scenes that I viewed to be somewhat repetitive, and maybe I was just in the wrong mood, but I was confused by the fantasy; I re-watched portions to understand why certain beings were turned into stone. All in all, I recommend this movie for youngsters, and adults alike. I recommended it to a friend who has young teens--I thought the story was sufficiently sophisticated to appeal to her kids, who are 16 year old twins.

They're quest through the fairy realm reveals symbolism which echoes they're own lives and helps them unravel a mystery about their mother and resolve a long standing sibling rivalry. This movie is beautiful and a little sad, but not overly so. It is rated PG. I have a 8 and 5 year old daughters, and we all absolutely loved it! As inspiring as any Miyazaki film! Highly recommended!

Admittedly, I had never heard of this movie until its nomination at the Oscars. But after seeing a bunch of clips, and reading a ton of nice reviews about it, I decided to give it a watch, and was utterly blown away.

On a lighthouse hilltop in Ireland lives two kids and their dad. Ben, the older brother, is both sad and angry at the mysterious disappearance of his mother, and he takes his frustration out on his younger sister, Saoirse, who, despite being six years old, has yet to start talking.  On the night of her birthday, Saoirse puts on a strange, white coat, and, upon entering the ocean, discovers she's a selkie; a girl who can magically change into a seal. In order to keep her origins a secret, her dad sends both her and her brother to live with their grandmother in the far away city. But the kids can't run from destiny forever, and when a scheming owl witch kidnaps Saoirse, it's up to Ben to summon all his courage and newfound brotherly love to save his sister, who holds the key to saving all of the magical creatures in Ireland.

First off, the artwork and animation in this is utterly incredible and beautiful. After seeing so many CGI animated movies, it was nice to see something traditionally animated again, and we REALLY need to lobby for more classic animation again, especially if it turns out looking like this. Often times, the artwork looks like a storybook come to life, and that serves the story well, considering much of the plot revolves around old folklore and keeping fairy tales alive.  If you liked cartoon shows like "Samurai Jack", or any of Hayao Miyazaki's work, you'll definitely enjoy this.  There's a lot of slow and quiet moments, allowing the audience to soak up the scenery, and not rely on constant talking to get the plot across.

While there's very few characters, they're all a nice bunch.  Saoirse, despite being mute for almost the entire movie, is a sweet and adventurous girl, and you can always tell what's she's trying to say or what's on her mind just in her movements and expressions.  Ben goes through a lot of development; starting off as being very jealous and resentful of his sister, but over time, comes to understand their sad circumstances aren't her fault, and learns to love her; risking his life to save hers. Even the owl witch isn't really evil; she steals and locks away the emotions of herself and others, thinking they'll be better off that way, and not realizing she's only making her and everyone's personal pain worse.  In a sense, she's very similar to Ben and Saoirse's father, who tries hiding the truth about magic; not understanding that he's only creating more sadness and more problems by not facing them.  The other magical creatures that appear get relatively small parts, but each of them are funny and memorable, and taught me a lot more about the figures of Irish folklore, and makes me want to look them up and learn more about them.

This is one movie that's truly a masterpiece of art, and deserves a lot more attention.  Now I really want to look up this studio's other raved about movie, "The Secret of Kells".

My wife and our 15 yr old son watched and I watched Song of the Sea because we loved Secret of Kells.  We've seen that film many times, and my son still can sing the cat's song.  The animation of Song of the Sea is often astonishingly beautiful, so the film is worth seeing.  However, the plot is derivative and the story is not told well.

Children's movies aren't something I gravitate to now that I'm an adult, but I still am on the lookout for interesting animated films that have intelligence and maturity. Sadly, the US is sorely lacking in that department, with Disney having (seemingly) lost its way. Thankfully, I am able to find what I'm looking for with animated offerings from other countries, and SONG OF THE SEA is just the latest of these discoveries (for me). SONG OF THE SEA is loosely adapted from an Irish/Scottish legend about women (mostly) who can exist in seal form. That was something I had to look up to more fully understand this rich mythology, which might be a sizable learning curve for someone who isn't from Ireland or Scotland, but the story told in this film should be understandable and relatable on an emotional and intellectual level by anyone who chooses to watch it. I really don't want to give away any of the story at all because doing so would spoil the experience of seeing it for the first time. The film generally deals with family, loss and magic, which should be enough going in. The magical elements will appeal to children, as will the young protagonists, while the adults will be able enjoy the allegorical and symbolic layers that gradually unveil themselves as the film progresses. Aside from a few narrative conveniences, I thought that this film was exceptionally crafted and emotionally involving. I should also mention the animation style, which had a watercolor-like/storybook feel to it and gently moved between soft, impressionistic images and more angular, expressionistic ones. If I had to make a comparison, the character design reminded me a little bit of PERSEPOLIS, but this film is in full color and uses it to beautiful effect. Ultimately, I hardly found any fault at all here and this Oscar-nominated film deserves to seen more than it has. A definite "see it."

HERES A princess of the Celtic-kind for you. And her brother, a true prince of a lad  although it takes a while for him to get his bearings.

Like director Tomm Moores The Secret of Kells (2009), Song of the Sea was nominated for Best Animated Feature Film at the Academy Awards. A high honor and well deserved for this charming tale of two siblings, born of a lighthouse keeper father and a selkie mother, a fairy creature who lives in the sea and becomes human on dry land once shedding her magical fur. Theyre a kind of Celtic version of the mermaid myth, Moore says in his lyrical commentary.

Selkie stories  like many Irish tales  are a bit melancholy. Things rarely work out well for the lovely creatures and Song of the Sea doesn't skew this point. How could they? Moore says he was inspired when on holiday with his son in the west of Ireland. He was just beginning work on Kells and they were sketching on the beach when the child noticed dead seals on the shore. A local woman advised that the fishermen had started killing seals out of frustration because of the falling fish stock.

I found out that [that] had much more to do with human intervention than anything to do with the seals, he tells us. The woman went on to say the killings wouldn't have happened in the past, that there was more respect for sea life and a belief that permeated the local culture that seals could be selkies, people that could transform into seals, or they might be the souls of people whod been lost at sea. That got Moore thinking about how folklore had once been more integrated into peoples daily life, a life that also helped protect the environment and led to a more balanced way of living.

Maybe, Moore says, we were losing more than stories.

Song of the Sea takes Irish legend into contemporary times, where magic weaves its spell throughout the city and buses and dumps as well as the land and sea. It also tells a tale of sibling rivalry. Young Ben is stuck with a little sister, Saoirse, who seems to get all his fathers love and attention after their mothers disappearance. Its not true, but from Bens point of view, nothing in his life is exactly right or fair. When Saoirse finds her own magic fur and takes off into the sea to swim with the seals, her father and grandmother are frantic with worry. They have no idea  or will not accept  that her magic works. Ben and Saoirse are bundled off with the old woman to live in the city. Dad packs up Saoirses fur and throws it into the sea.

Leaving his home and his dog only upsets Ben more. Distance from the water sickens Saoirse, and soon the two are running away together, heading back home. Thats when they begin to discover the enchantments that literally saturate their homeland and how it is endangered, particularly by a bitter old witch, who wants to bottle up all feeling, a misguided attempt to help her centuries-old son thats turned to stone because of grief.

Only Saoirses magic can help them all  and only if Ben can find a way past his own loss to help his little sister.

Whew  thats pretty deep for a fairy tale. Still, it all works in a way both children and adults can enjoy. One of its many charms is that it never talks down to us or simplifies the characters emotions. Even granny and the old witch are motivated by the love inside their damaged hearts.

Like Kells, Song of the Sea boasts a unique animation style that speaks of illustrated books and it is gorgeous to watch. The backgrounds tell a story as well as the characters making this worthy of many repeat viewings on the Blu-rays HD transfer. Colors are rich; the atmosphere golden and warm, even under water. A DTS-HD Master Audio 5.1 soundtrack balances effects, ambient sound and a haunting score by Bruno Coulais in a masterful surround-sound experience.

In addition to Moores commentary  which sounds like a fairy tale itself told in his Celtic brogue  Universal presents a nice package of bonus features. Behind the Scenes can be viewed with or without Moores explanations, while Animation Tests, a concept trailer and The Art of Song of the Sea reveal some of the secrets behind this animated story.

Song of the Sea is an enchanting tale of family and magic in the tradition of My Neighbor Totoro. It is highly recommended for all.   Kay Reynolds

There is a character in "Song of the Sea" called 'The Great Shanachie', which is also a fitting title for the author/director, Tomm Moore.

In a style that resonates at the most fundamental human levels, Mr. Moore presents a tale of legend, of discovery, heroism...and, most of all...the importance of family. "Song of the Sea" is, on the surface a tale of the Shelties...seals who can turn to beautiful women and sometimes marry human men. In Mr. Moore's hands, the tale is about the impact of loss on the human heart; and, how in trying to end the pain, the soul can be lost. Yet, it is a tale of hope...of how in the simple act of raising one's eyes from the ashes of lost dreams, one may find that the dreams have always remained...simply out of sight.

If I wax poetic, forgive me. This film is incredibly human, with a depth of story and characterization that makes many 'live' films pale in comparison. It is like something you would expect to listen to at dusk, in front of a turf fire with the strains of a Celtic harp singing all around you. Add to that, an utterly unique and beautiful animation style that enables the film to achieve the dreamlike state of myth.

Utterly beguiling and suitable for all ages, the "Song of the Sea" is a film to be cherished, and handed down to the next generation.

Tomm Moore and Will Collins have done it again. This wonderful movie for all ages introduces the audience to the heart of some Irish legends and folklore.  The superb animation is a wonderful follow up to there groundbreaking and spectacular previous feature "The Secret of Kells."  For those familiar with Irish history and legends, both films are filled with delightful story lines and references to the some of the best tales the Irish have to offer.  Add to that the stunning visual imagination of the marvelous production team and these films soar as some of the best animation in recent film history.  I have used "Secret of Kells" in my Celtic Spirituality course at Concordia College in Moorhead, Minnesota and it is a highlight for many students.  I will add this film to the class in the future. This reviewer only hopes that there are many more films from this gifted group of film makers who do not compromise on intricate imaginative style in the midst of master story telling.  I highly recommend these films.

As I was looking through the 2015 Oscar nominees for Best Animated Picture, I came across the title "Song of the Sea."  I already figured it had little to no chance of winning, as Disney and/or Pixar usually take home the statuette every year (a personal pet peeve of mine, but nothing I can do about it), but immediately the concept of this film intrigued me.  One doesn't often hear much about movies made in Ireland, and if an Irish movie was notable enough to garner an Oscar in a field largely dominated by American and Japanese animation, it had to be something special.  And the fact that it featured creatures of Irish folklore -- including selkies, one of my favorite underrated mythical creatures -- was an added bonus.

I'm happy I gave this film a chance.  It's adorable, exquisitely animated, and overall beautifully done.

"Song of the Sea" is centered on two children who live with their father in a lighthouse on an island off the coast of Ireland -- Ben, resentful that his mother has abandoned their family, and Saoirse, his mute little sister whom Ben blames for the death/disappearance of their mother.  When Saoirse discovers a beautiful white fur coat and ventures into the sea with it, nearly drowning, their grandmother decides their father is incapable of taking care of the children and takes them to live with her in the city.  Ben is determined to return to his father, however, and he and Saoirse set off through the city to find their way home.  But on the way, they encounter a troupe of Ireland's Fair Folk, who reveal that Saoirse is a selkie -- a girl with the ability to turn into a seal if she can just find her sealskin -- and that if she can find her fur coat and her voice, her song will save all the faerie creatures from Macha, the fearsome Owl Witch who is turning the faerie creatures to stone.  But the children's father has gone to great lengths to hide Saoirse's coat... and even with the help of the faerie folk, will they be too late to save them... and Saoirse?

This film is beautifully animated, with a unique visual style that's quite pleasing to the eye.  It's not quite anime-ish, but the large eyes and the lush landscapes will call to mind the works of Miyazaki and Studio Ghibli.  And when many studios have given up 2D animation in favor of CGI and 3D animation, it's nice to see the art form hasn't entirely died out, and even better to see it used to create something so beautiful.

The characters are oddly bland in this film, and Ben starts off as an unlikable brat, but thankfully he, at least, develops over the course of the film and gradually becomes more likable.  Saoirse is more of a static character, almost more of a plot device than an actual character, but she's oddly adorable and it's hard not to like her.  And even the two villains of the movie, the grandmother and the Owl Witch, aren't without good traits -- it's obvious the grandmother wants to help the children and means no malice, and even the Owl Witch believes her intentions are good in what she's doing.  One can draw some obvious parallels between these two characters...

In contrast to a lot of American animation, "Song of the Sea" is quieter and more atmospheric, not relying on a bombastic musical score or a lot of slapstick humor to hold the audience's attention.  Thus, it may not be for small children, or for people more used to the brisk, almost frantic pace of most modern animated films.  But for those who are fans of Miyazaki's work, or are willing to be patient, this movie is quite rewarding.  It takes time to set the atmosphere and let mysteries reveal themselves without a lot of exposition, and that makes it well worth watching.

Beautiful and a lovely showcase of some of the lesser-known creatures of Irish mythology, this is a great film for those who want an animated feature that's a little bit different from the norm.  And if you like Studio Ghibli's work, give "Song of the Sea" a watch.  You won't be disappointed.

This is a lovely film that weaves ancient Irish stories and visual design elements with a contemporary tale of a family learning to cope with grief, fear, and one another after a great loss. While the plot may seem a bit obvious to adults, particularly to those familiar with selkie lore, I found the specifics of this telling delightful. It's visually clever as well as aesthetically pleasing, and contains wonderful - and refreshing, in western film  messages about the power of acknowledging feelings, good and bad; about the vital importance of remembering the old songs and stories; and that heroic feats are achieved, not individually, but by family members learning to appreciate, champion, and rely on one another despite their vast differences.

I just got out from watching this film in the theaters and immedietly ordered this film on blu-ray. For those who don't know, This is the second full length animated film, after The Secret of Kells, from up and coming Irish studio Cartoon Saloon, and revolves around Ben and Saoirse (pronounced sear-sha), and their struggles after learning that Saoirse is a selkie, a creature in Irish mythology that turns into a seal when in the water. The film is heavily influenced by a number of aspects, predominately Irish culture and lore. You don't need to know any of it to watch (I didn't), but you will probably get more out of it the more you know.

Song of the Sea shows how much Cartoon Saloon has already learned in the span of one movie. The Song of the Sea is better than Kells in almost every conceivable way. It's animation is crisper, its music is more gorgeous, it has a better story, better pacing, and more relatable characters. My biggest qualm with The Secret of Kells was that the ending seemed incredibly rushed, and Song of the Sea remedies this beautifully. It is exactly film I wanted when Cartoon Saloon was first advertising it.

It is not a perfect movie. It did have some problems with it, notably a slow start, a few characters being overly eccentric, just for the sake of it. There are some frames that stick out, and the film often flips in between exuberance and fear too abruptly. Also, it may have been because I was spoiled on the ending accidentally, but it felt that the film had trouble inducing a sense of tension near the climax of the movie. However despite that, this movie still ended up being one of my favorite films period of 2013, and easily makes it into my top two spot along with Kaguya.

If you're a fan of animation, and you have not yet seen this film, you owe it to yourself to watch it. It truly is a wonder to behold the amazing animation, beautiful music, enthralling lore, and amazing adventure that ties this film together.

Cons include; a tricky plot to follow, might need to use subtitles if you are put off by Irish Gaelic moments, and its a crash course in Irish Folklore- if you've never read or heard Irish Lore then the references are going to be a little difficult.

(Spoiler alert!!) I enjoyed The Secret of Kells, so I was excited to watch this animated film... and was equally enchanted by it! I've always been fascinated by tales of the selkie, and this film gave me exactly what I was looking for: beautiful animation, haunting yet lovely music, a fun, lively adventure, and a happy ending! The story is about overcoming pain and learning to love. Even though this young boy is experiencing an overwhelming amount of anguish and resentment after losing his mother while giving birth to his little sister, he manages to put his grief aside in order to help his sick little half-human, half-selkie sibling. And in doing so, he learns how to open his heart and truly love. It's a movie I'd most definitely watch again! Simply lovely!!
Don't hesitate. Please don't wonder. This is a movie for a family, a date night, alone - it's simply a phenomenal storytelling experience.

Song of the Sea is an extraordinary film illustrated through the tender and magical artistic vision of Director Tomm Moore (Secret of the Kells) about Selkies, an ancient Irish mythological species of creatures attached to the sea. The story takes us through young boy Ben's journey of losing a mother, and, subsequently his his sister, Saoirse, while simultaneously reminding us of humankind's journey of losing our connection to Mother Earth. Ben must find compassion within himself to understand that his sister is different than he is, and garner the courage to protect her differences through overcoming his own prejudices about the role she played in his mother's death while dealing with an emotinally absent father. The movie deals with these issues gently but profoundly, through the magic of the natural and mythological world. I highly recommend this film for anyone who enjoys a fairytale that brings tenderness into his or her life.

This has to be one of the best animated films I have ever seen in my life.  I was a huge fan of their previous work, "The Secret of Kells," but this movie makes the former seem like a warm-up for films to come.  I am also a huge fan of the works of Studio Ghibli, especially those of Hayao Miyazaki, however, I think that Tomm Moore is swiftly becoming my favorite director of animated films.  Beautiful art and animation, a perfect musical score, and an enchanting story that rivals other notable films such as "Spirited Away" and "Howl's Moving Castle."  A must-see movie suitable for everyone.

I blind bought this Blu-ray because of the critical acclaim and my lukewarm fondness of the studio's past film, "Book of Kells". I couldn't have been more blown away and this is now one of my favorite movies of all time!

Everyone from Mom & Dad to our 5 kids (ages 2-7) was completely engrossed, and it even caused my 6-year-old to put down her iPad mid-game, which not many movies can do! :-)

The hand-drawn animation is gorgeous, stylized, and distinctively Irish in the country- and sea-side settings and Celtic-style art.

However, the real strength of the movie is in the rich personalities of the characters and their engrossing struggles; from the young boy who resents his adorable little sister, to an intimidating and charismatic witch who tries to steer the quest off course, to the parents and grandparents of the children, whose involvement in the story nearly left me in tears (of both joy and sorrow) at times.

This movie easily qualifies as a masterpiece and distinguishes itself in a "sea" of computer animated kid films which tend to shy away from such emotional subject matter as this movie contains.

I have been wanting to watch this movie for months on end and finally I was able to wrap my hands around it and I have to say that it was well worth the wait. After watching the Tale of Princess Kaguya this year, I thought that no other animation film could beat it for the year but I believe Song of the Sea did just that. This movie is wonderful in every single way from storytelling to the visuals and even to the music. This is my review of Song of the Sea.
___________

NARRATIVE: The primary characters in this this movie is Ben and Saoirse who are brother and sister. Ben's mother abandoned him and his father when Ben was a young child but lefther new child behind who is Saoirse. Six years later Ben begins to resent Saoirse and often blames her for everything wrong that has happened to him. Saoirse is a quiet 6 year old girl who still hasn't learned how to talk yet and it has become a mystery  for Ben's father who often is gloomy and detached after his wife had mysteriously left him 6 years ago. This is where the story kicks off and I will not say anymore to prevent spoilers.

Throughout the narrative, we get to see the character progression of young Ben and how he grows up in the story along with his relationship with Saoirse. The story takes elements from Irish Mythology and works itself into the story really well. It kind of reminded me of Spirited Away a couple of times during the story because that movie too is based off Japanese mythology in similar fashion. The ending was beautiful and heartbreaking as well and definitely left an impression. This movie is extremely memorable.
__________

ARTWORK: I was captivated by the artwork done in this movie from the very beginning where I saw the lighthouse on the cliff all the way to the ending credits. The design of the film is highly based of the Book of Kells which was the studio's previous movie but it significantly improves upon it. The whole film is done in a 2D backdrop but it is extremely well executed. I truly appreciate the work that they have put into this film in terms of animation and design. The scenery is beautiful and the colors just pop like eye candy.
___________

MUSIC: The music is gorgeous. What can I say? This movie is downright perfect. The main song "Song of the Sea" is played multiple times throughout the narrative but it does not seem annoying in any way. It captures the essence of the film and will captivate you every time you hear it. I know it sounds like I am fangirling here, but trust me the sound is just magnificent.
___________

CONCLUSION: This movie is a must watch for everyone out there. I can't seem to think of anyone who wouldn't love this film. Go out there and watch it now! BengirlxD approved.

There is no doubt that this - aside from The Wind Rises and The Tale of the Princess Kaguya - is the most beautiful animated film of the last two years, hands-down. I just couldn't get behind the utterly and deliberately sexist themes of the story. It's the 21st Century, and we still have women's rights issues around the world. Why are we propagating more of this in the art and film world?

Throughout the tale, we see a young boy as the centerpiece, responsible for his sister, a grand quest full of peril, and saving the world from turning to stone. Meanwhile, his sister is also in every scene, but is treated like an object rather than a person - bullied, tugged around on a leash, and not even given the ability to speak. And when she finally does speak, the first thing she says is the boy's name. And she appears to readily accept a brief apology for the years of torment he put her through.

The other females of the tale either exist as the magical "other," unattainable by humans and therefore also objects to covet, or are inane, or just plain evil.

And it's the women that trigger the greatest pain and suffering of the story: mother selkie destroys the emotional stability of a human family out of selfishness, old witch turns everyone to stone also out of selfishness, grandmother takes kids away from their father also out of selfishness.

I want to like this film. I really do. My question is this: what is its message to the young girls of the world?

Absolutely beautifully done, just as Secret of Kells was. I loved the intertwining of various Irish myths and the artistic style is stunning. Going on my Top 10 shelf, and highly recommending to everyone I meet.

Another gorgeous film from the gang at the Cartoon Saloon. Honest, straight forward storytelling tucked between some of the most beautiful art you will ever see on screen. Anyone who watches this and doesn't tear up by the end is either dead or has a heart of stone.

This is an awesome, heartfelt movie with a simple message 'Don't avoid your emotions or you could turn to stone!' There were tears streaming down my face as I watched the film, and I left the theater grounded with a resolve to 'man up' and make some changes in my life. That, in itself was enough for me to rate it five stars, but everything else about the film is superb as well!
You don't have to be Irish to appreciate this film, that would defeat its purpose and message! As a first generation Irish-American I was already familiar with the superstitions & folklore surrounding the selkies and fairies. As a 'born again Celtic pagan' I had studied Celtic mythology to gain a deeper understand of my roots. They brought those elements to the film with a light touch, as a backdrop for the human story, without becoming heavy handed or preaching. Everything about the film (music, animation, art, storyline, etc.) really worked for me, and I will buy the DVD to share with my friends!

This should have gotten the Oscar in a year full of great films.
There is no question that nearly all of the talked about animated films had great animation, I won't talk about plot since simplicity is key in this section of the entertainment industry, so my criteria is simple yet off topic to most people; what did I feel thanks to the feel.

SPOILERS FOR ALMSOT EVERY ANIMATED FILM IN 2014 (but I will try to be vague).

How to Train your dragon 2 tried to give us a story about losing the ability to make peace and learning how to man up and save the day, but it did not grab my heart that tightly.
Big Hero 6 gave me coping with grief and the futility of revenge, but not strong enough.
Box Trolls had a moral of self determination which includes not trying to succeed by society's standards.
The Lego Movie was a glorious kick in the face to Joseph Cambells Power Of Myth philosophy and much needed penicillin for the mentality of the industry, but as poignant as that is it was a touch far from the human condition to resonate beyond that context.
The Tale of Princess Kaguya had a "be careful what you wish for" moral coupled with the trials of being seen as an object and prized by others. That honestly gave me a fresh viewpoint on an experience of being a woman (I say "an" because all humans are complicated and I hate to generalize).
Kaguya would have my vote for opening my eyes for the oscars......until I found a familiar emotion in Song of the Sea that I had yet seen articulated in film at large; the tragedy of selflessly helping someone and hurting them in the process. It is in a subplot, but choosing between kaguya revealing an experience someone else felt and Song of the Sea showing me something I have seen and never articulated, THAT IS MOVIE MAKING. It changed a core way I understood the world and gave it a face and poetry. Not a flight of fantasy, not a reinforcement, not a comment on something trendy, not a new experience that is still distant from me, but it gave me myself in a way I did not think was possible. That can only be achieved by extraordinary coincidence or truly insightful writing and directing and considering my friends feel the same way I would like to believe the later.

I am going to preorder this movie rather than hunt it down later for a cheaper price. These writers and animators deserve every dime I can spare.

'Secret of Kells' was a brilliant movie, rich in imagery, characterization, and history. The same team put together this masterpiece, too, and it wholly deserves its Oscar nomination. The plot centers on a very human family (dog included), of a small boy (Ben), his younger sister (Saoirse, 'seer-shah') and their widowed father. Saoirse's cute, eager, and intelligent, but still hasn't spoken at age six. We find out she's a Selkie, as at home in the water as a seal as much as on land as a girl. A bit of family drama separate the children form their father, in an unhappy and unfamilar environment - and the real story begins.

It turns into a grand quest, with fairies, giants, an owl-witch, and other magical beings of no easy description. And with a doom descending on the magical world that only Saoirse can forestall. This combines elements of mythology whit things like high voltage power line towers seamlessly, imbuing even the most mundane objects with wonder and menace. Dozens of the movie's elements seem to draw on traditional myths and stories - none of which I'm familiar with, adding a touch more mystery to the magic.

But, however much I like the story (and that's a lot), the telling is what you'll remember. The cartoons are visually lush in more different ways than I can name - you really have to see them. And the music! Sound tracks don't often stick in my mind, but the centrality of music and song in this story helps make it memorable. Although completely kid-friendly (unless your little one is very skittish), adults of any age can enjoy this - and maybe even more than the kids do.

--wiredweird

About a month ago, I saw THE SECRET OF KELLS, which I found delightful enough. I was determined to catch the filmmaker, Tomm Moore's, most recent Oscar-nominated animated feature while it was still in theaters, so I jumped at the chance to see SONG OF THE SEA when a couple of showings cropped up near me.

Tomm Moore's fully hand-drawn story spirals color and pattern and wisps of details as it recounts a tale stemming from Irish and Scottish legend: a legend of the Selkies, women who walk the land as humans but swim the sea as seals. Our story focuses on Saoirse (Lucy O'Connell), a mute six-year-old girl and the last of the Selkies, being raised by her single father (Brendan Gleeson) and ignored by her older brother, Ben. The one-sided rivalry between Ben and Saoirsehe feeds on his resentment because he blames her for their mother's deatheventually leads to his discovery of her magical origin... and the role she's meant to play in saving the remnants of the mystical world.

This may be a fantasy, but it's really about a family, and a relationship between siblings when a tragedy is constantly hanging overhead. Their evolution as brother and sister IS the story. Everything else is secondary, but it is hardly nothing. Moore constructs a nearly flawless movie, one like I've never seen before. His feature, THE SECRET OF KELLS, was similarly beautiful, stylistically, but it didn't have the heart that this one does. By the end, my heart had nearly burst from love for little Saoirse and the endlessly loyal Ben.

By far, the best animated feature of 2014, if not the last few years. It is pure magic, and precious without sacrificing its storytelling for that warm, fuzzy feeling. Even though, yes, that feeling is there, too. I walked away pondering the themes, the implications... it actually reminded me of my feelings walking out of PAN'S LABYRINTHso many incredible possibilities, all of them adding layer upon layer of meaning. Do yourself a favor and see this movie. Now.
